bestBHT.bht: The lawyer's answer showed his knowledge of the law, as he quoted from the Shema prayer, specifically Deuteronomy 6:5 and Leviticus 19:18. This signifies the importance of loving God with every part of one's being, including the heart, soul, strength, and mind. Jesus affirms this comprehensive love, emphasizing the need for wholehearted devotion and service to God. This response reflects the lawyer's understanding that loving God and loving one's neighbor are central to the fulfillment of the law.

Henry Alford: The first part of this, together with Deut. xi. 13 ff., the Jews had written on their phylacteries, and recited night and morning.
Meyer thinks the man answered thus, because he had before heard our Lord cite these in connexion, and with an especial view to asking the question 'who is my neighbour?'
The words willing to justify Himself seem to imply this; but see below.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: answer Christ Himself gave to another lawyer. (See on :-).
Marvin Vincent: Thou shalt love, etc. See on Mark 12:30. Luke adds strength.
THE PARABLE OF THE GOOD SAMARITAN,
Philip Schaff: This answer of the lawyer showed intelligence; he gives the sum of the whole law.
But his knowledge of the law exceeded his self-knowledge.
For in addition to Deuteronomy 6:5, which he quotes first, the Jews had written upon the phylacteries and recited night and morning, not this passage, but Deuteronomy 11:13, etc.
Archibald T. Robertson: The lawyer's answer is first from the Shema...which was written on the phylacteries.
The second part is from Leviticus 19:18 and shows that the lawyer knew the law.
God is to be loved with all of man's four powers (heart, soul, strength, mind) here as in Mark 12:30.
John Gill: And he answering said, thou shalt love the Lord thy God,.... This was part of their phylacteries, which they recited every day; :- :- :- :-
John Wesley: Thou shalt unite all the faculties of thy soul to render him the most intelligent and sincere, the most affectionate and resolute service.
We may safely rest in this general sense of these important words, if we are not able to fix the particular meaning of every single word.

With all thy soul, with the warmest affection, with all thy strength, the most vigorous efforts of thy will, and with all thy mind or understanding, in the most wise and reasonable manner thou canst; thy understanding guiding thy will and affections.

bhtAttempts.bht: The lawyer in the passage answers Jesus' question by quoting from the shema, the Jewish prayer recited morning and night. This shows that the lawyer knew the law well. The first part of his answer comes from Deuteronomy 6:5 and signifies the love and devotion that should be directed towards God. The second part, from Leviticus 19:18, emphasizes the love that should be shown to one's neighbor. Loving God with all of one's heart, soul, strength, and mind entails uniting all facets of one's being in service to Him. This comprehensive love is what Jesus affirms in response to the lawyer's question.

The lawyer's answer, sourced from the Shema prayer, demonstrates his knowledge of the law and the importance of wholehearted devotion to God. By quoting Deuteronomy 6:5 and Leviticus 19:18, he highlights the love that should be directed towards God and one's neighbor. Loving God requires the unity of one's heart, soul, strength, and mind, encompassing all aspects of one's being. Jesus affirms this comprehensive love, emphasizing the significance of wholehearted service to God.

The lawyer's answer showed his knowledge of the law, as he quoted from the Shema prayer, specifically Deuteronomy 6:5 and Leviticus 19:18. This signifies the importance of loving God with every part of one's being, including the heart, soul, strength, and mind. Jesus affirms this comprehensive love, emphasizing the need for wholehearted devotion and service to God. This response reflects the lawyer's understanding that loving God and loving one's neighbor are central to the fulfillment of the law.

The lawyer's response reveals his knowledge of the law, as he quotes the Shema prayer, Deuteronomy 6:5, and Leviticus 19:18. By citing these passages, he emphasizes the importance of loving God with all of one's heart, soul, strength, and mind, and loving one's neighbor as oneself. Jesus affirms this comprehensive love, highlighting the necessity of wholehearted devotion and service to God. The lawyer's answer reflects an understanding that genuine love for God and others is central to fulfilling the law's requirements.

The lawyer demonstrates his knowledge of the law by quoting the Shema prayer, specifically Deuteronomy 6:5 and Leviticus 19:18. This signifies the importance of wholeheartedly loving God with one's heart, soul, strength, and mind, as well as loving one's neighbor as oneself. Jesus affirms this all-encompassing love, emphasizing the need for genuine devotion and sincere service to God. The lawyer's response highlights the fundamental principle of loving God and others, which lies at the core of fulfilling the law.
